stream_context.summary: Kaze models and scripts Course 11 (working title “Oily Boily Bay”), focusing on new wind-turbine platform mechanics, red-coin layout, and performance considerations while keeping the ROM under 64 MB. He briefly demos Course 1 on real N64 to show major engine optimisations.

development_findings.summary: Return to Yoshi’s Island currently weighs 42.8 MB (course 11 of 15) and is being kept within the 64 MB cartridge limit.
development_findings.quote: We are in course 11 and we are 42.8 megabytes in size, so yes, this ROM will be staying in the 64 megabyte limitations.

development_findings.summary: Course 11 mission list (working names): 1) Troll the Balsa Troops; 2) The Minions Are Striking (player is swallowed and taken to a cleaning-crew sub-area); 3) Knock Off Bowser’s Hat; plus a boss and generator sequence.
development_findings.quote: The first is Troll the Balsa Troops… second we have The Minions Are Striking… you’re gonna be eaten by a block… then you will go up here and knock off Bowser’s hat.

development_findings.summary: Horizontal and vertical wind turbines are introduced as new platforming devices; they can blow or suck Mario and will toggle on timed intervals (8 s on, 2 s off).
development_findings.quote: We might as well have one horizontal one and one vertical one… off for like two seconds and then on for like eight seconds.

development_findings.summary: Implemented turbine actor with angle-based physics, particle feedback, and speed capping; overcame gimbal-lock issues by pre-rotating the model 90° in Blender.
development_findings.quote: MFs will never believe you how hard it was to make this thing spin this way – I had to rotate the model in 3D because Euler angles kept locking.

development_findings.summary: Red-coin mission will centre on turbines, moving cranes, hooks, and modular platforms inspired by Rico Harbor; star spawns are being tuned for single-jump reachability.
development_findings.quote: I definitely want one red coin you get by just jumping on a turbine and going up… we know Mario will have 48 speed and around 80 vertical.

development_findings.summary: Blue-coin switch graphics are slated for redesign; current placeholder is considered "super ugly."
development_findings.quote: We still need a redesigned blue coin switch – the one we have right now is super ugly.

development_findings.summary: Engine optimisations (cache-box, draw-distance, interp) raise real N64 performance from single-digits to ~40–50 FPS; infinite draw distance now feasible.
development_findings.quote: Look at this – this is an N64 game… The zoo was 9 FPS on the original engine and now it’s like 40, 50.

development_findings.summary: Camera behaviour was tweaked after feedback from Lila to improve feel.
development_findings.quote: We changed the camera since last time… Lila was complaining about it and I kind of saw her point.

development_findings.summary: Poly-budget awareness: final turbine settled at 44 triangles; i cosphere rejected as too heavy (150 tris).
development_findings.quote: This is 150 triangles, which is kind of a lot… this one is 44 – come on, we’re fine.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s bike was stolen, putting him in a bad mood at stream start.
context_findings.quote: I’m in a bad mood because my bike was stolen.

context_findings.summary: Currently editing a video on sine/cosine approximations and a separate conference talk on N64 hacking; aims to publish the math video in ~2 weeks.
context_findings.quote: I’m working on a new video… it should be releasing, I think, two weeks from now – it’s about sine and cosine approximations.

context_findings.summary: April 1st meme video outperformed serious content; Kaze reflects that YouTube now rewards "background-noise" length and may make annual verbose joke videos.
context_findings.quote: Even though that [grass] video was an April Fool’s joke, it did better than most of my normal videos.

context_findings.summary: He dislikes excessive player-options; prefers designed defaults over menu toggles.
context_findings.quote: People are asking for options on every little detail… at that point, just make your own game.

context_findings.summary: Vacation next week; expects more streaming time.
context_findings.quote: I’m gonna have a vacation in a week too, so with that vacation I can probably stream a lot.

context_findings.summary: Diagnosed with tennis elbow; refused cortisol injections and painkillers, opting to self-treat.
context_findings.quote: He [doctor] might have to inject steroids… I said nah, I’ll just treat myself.

biobak.summary: Searched for and provided missing texture files; offered to recreate them if lost.
biobak.quote: Biobak, the only issue I have is trying to track the damn thing down – it might just be faster to recreate it.

biobak.summary: Designed a new YouTube stream banner during the stream; Kaze approved and applied it.
biobak.quote: That’s a very cool stream banner. I like this.

key_stories.title: The Turbine Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted wind turbines that physically push Mario. Initial Blender model caused gimbal-lock issues in the engine, making correct rotation impossible.
key_stories.challenge: Euler-angle limitations prevented the turbine from spinning on the intended axis.
key_stories.process: Tried altering pitch, roll and yaw in code; ultimately rotated the mesh 90° in Blender and created a duplicate model for horizontal use.
key_stories.outcome: Working vertical and horizontal turbine actors with timed on/off states, 44-triangle models, and particle feedback.
key_stories.key_quote: MFs will never believe you how hard it was to make this thing spin this way around.

key_stories.title: Engine Performance Leap
key_stories.summary: Course 1 was re-shown on real N64 to demonstrate dramatic FPS gains after core engine rewrites.
key_stories.challenge: Early builds ran at ~9 FPS with heavy scenes.
key_stories.process: Implemented cache-box optimisation, draw-distance handling and frame interpolation; rewrote rendering pipeline.
key_stories.outcome: Same scene now holds 40–50 FPS with infinite draw distance, giving a GameCube-like look.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s not crazy to say anymore that this looks like a GameCube game.

key_stories.title: Content vs Algorithm
key_stories.summary: An April Fool’s grass-joke video outperformed technical showcases, leading Kaze to reassess YouTube strategy.
key_stories.challenge: Labour-intensive videos underperform vs meme content.
key_stories.process: Reviewed analytics; discussed making yearly verbose joke videos and pivoting toward background-friendly content.
key_stories.outcome: Plans annual April 1st tradition; remains conflicted about balancing depth and reach.
key_stories.key_quote: This stupid meme video, 160k; my revolutionising N64 programming, less than grass – how insulting.

open_questions.context: Kaze calls current graphic "super ugly" and lacks a better concept.
questions: What visual language do you want for blue-coin switches?
Who will own the redesign task?
Any technical constraints (size, animation) to consider?

open_questions.context: Level is oil-flooded; brainstormed oil spots but no settled gameplay.
questions: Will oil change movement physics or damage Mario?
Any planned visual effects (heat waves, reflections)?
How will oil interact with turbines or enemies?

open_questions.context: Kaze debates having a “fuck-you hard” final area but worries about casual frustration.
questions: What criteria will decide if a super-hard final level is included?
Could optional post-game content satisfy both audiences?
Would checkpointing or assist mechanics undermine intended tension?

open_questions.context: Multiple underground entrances mentioned but no concrete design.
questions: What gameplay themes are planned for underground areas?
How will they visually differ from surface oil facility?
Any unique mechanics or enemies reserved for these zones?

open_questions.context: Chat suggested purchasable rescue bubbles; Kaze unconvinced.
questions: Are any accessibility aids planned (e.g., optional checkpoints)?
Could a Yoshi-salesman concept integrate assists without disrupting balance?
How will the team gauge difficulty for non-speedrunner players?
